revised_title: Observations of Saturn's Rings and Ansa
tldr: In two letters written in November 1671, John Flamstead shares his observations of Saturn using a 14-foot telescope. He describes the planet as appearing perfectly round, free from rays and colors, and without visible ansae (handles). He also mentions his friend's observation of a dark line through Saturn near its upper part. These observations contribute to the understanding of Saturn's rings and morphology.
